name: Number of integers with a shortest addition-multiplication chain of length n.
comment: a(n) is the number of occurrences of n in A230697.
author: _Pontus von Brömssen_, Apr 12 2025

name: Length of shortest addition-multiplication chain for n.
link: Jinyuan Wang, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
H. M. Bahig, On a generalization of addition chains: Addition-multiplication chains, Discrete Mathematics 308 (2008), 611-616
example: A shortest addition-multiplication chain for 16 is (1,2,4,16), of length a(16) = 3.

A shortest addition-multiplication chain for 913 is (1,2,3,9,11,81,83,913), of length a(913) = 7. This is the first case where not all terms in some shortest chain are the sum or product of the immediately preceding term and one more preceding term. In other words, 913 is the smallest of the analog of non-Brauer numbers (A349044) for addition-multiplication chains. The next ones are 996, 997, 998, 1012, 1077, 1079, 1542, 1572, 1575, 1589, 1792, 1795, 1816, ... . - _Pontus von Brömssen_, Apr 12 2025
author: _Harry Altman_, Oct 27 2013

name: Smallest number with shortest addition-multiplication chain of length n.
author: _Pontus von Brömssen_, Apr 12 2025
